intro_text: The patrol wants to hold a training session for app1.  They decide to focus on how best to use gusts of sand or dust to blind prey to attacks.
decline_text: They decide to focus on the patrolling the territory instead. Training can wait for another day.

success_outcomes.text: app1 listens carefully as the p_l explains how to spot a gust of wind approaching and how to exploit the noise and stinging sand during a hunt.
app1 picks up the instruction quickly, and the patrol plays a small game, freezing and only moving to tag each other during wind gusts to test {PRONOUN/app1/poss} abilities.
By the end of the patrol s_c is able to move steadily with the wind and sand, {PRONOUN/s_c/poss} movements sure and confident

fail_outcomes.text: app1 tries to track the wind gusts, but {PRONOUN/app1/subject} can't quite get the hang of it.
s_c struggles to take the lesson seriously, and the training session ends early with no real progress made.

intro_text: r_c wanders past an old badger sett overlooking a dried-up riverbed, only to freeze. There's new scent here, acrid and sour.
decline_text: Surely it must be nothing... Uneasily, r_c continues on.

success_outcomes.text: Feeling ever so alone on {PRONOUN/r_c/poss} solo patrol, r_c carefully sniffs around the mouth of the burrow, but the scent change is unmistakable - a new badger has moved in. Creeping forward, belly flat in the dirt, {PRONOUN/r_c/subject} {VERB/r_c/manage/manages} just enough of a glimpse to confirm the badger's presence before it moves, and r_c sprints back to camp to warn everyone.

Feeling ever so alone on {PRONOUN/r_c/poss} solo patrol, r_c carefully sniffs around the mouth of the burrow, but after a few moments, realizes that the scent is relatively weak. A badger was here, no doubt about it, but it doesn't seem to have taken up residence. This will be important information to report back at camp.

s_c decides there has to be a smarter way of figuring out if a badger has moved in - one that doesn't involve sticking {PRONOUN/s_c/poss} head in front of a predator. {PRONOUN/s_c/subject/CAP} {VERB/s_c/search/searches} the scrubland around the sett thoroughly and {VERB/s_c/come/comes} up with fresh badger scat: stinky, horrible, and perfect proof of the new occupant of the sett.

Carefully considering their options, r_c decides on stakeout and watches from a shaded vantage point. When the badger pokes its head above ground at dusk, {PRONOUN/r_c/subject}{VERB/r_c/'re/'s} prepared and {VERB/r_c/dart/darts} off back to camp to warn everyone before the predator has blinked the sleep out of its eyes.

fail_outcomes.text: Well, the only way to know is to check! s_c scrambles into the den for a look, and it's only by the grace of StarClan that {PRONOUN/s_c/subject}{VERB/s_c/'re/'s} able to redirect that speed to twist around just as fast, furious fizzing following {PRONOUN/s_c/object} up the burrow tunnel, leaving behind clumps of {PRONOUN/s_c/poss} own fur.

r_c carefully approaches the burrow, trying to figure out if there's anything new inside. It's so dark, and it all smells the same, so {PRONOUN/r_c/subject} {VERB/r_c/try/tries} to creep just a little closer - but the floor drops away steeply below {PRONOUN/r_c/poss} paws, and {PRONOUN/r_c/subject} {VERB/r_c/lose/loses} {PRONOUN/r_c/poss} grip, skidding downwards into a disturbed and lethal badger.

history_text.scar: m_c was scarred by a badger.
history_text.reg_death: m_c lost their life to a badger.

intro_text: p_l wanders past an old badger sett overlooking a dried-up riverbed, only to freeze. There's new scent here, acrid and sour.
decline_text: Surely it must be nothing... Uneasily, the patrol continues on.

success_outcomes.text: Calling the rest of the patrol over, the cats discuss their next move. If a badger has moved in, they need to confirm it. Eventually p_l comes up with a plan: sweeping the ground in front of the sett entrance clean with their tails. The cats will be able to come back tomorrow and see if anything has left tracks.

This can't be ignored. The patrol brainstorms ideas, until eventually they have a workable plan. p_l takes the most unpleasant job, gathering up fallen cacti spikes and thorny scrubs, and the cats gingerly push them down the slope of the badger set. Outraged, pained fizzing confirms the new occupant.

s_c decides there has to be a smarter way of figuring out if a badger has moved in - one that doesn't involve sticking {PRONOUN/s_c/poss} head in front of a predator. {PRONOUN/s_c/subject/CAP} {VERB/s_c/lead/leads} the patrol on a search of the scrubland around the sett, and they discover fresh badger scat: stinky, horrible, and perfect proof of the new occupant.

Carefully considering their options, s_c decides to set up a stakeout with the patrol. When the badger pokes its head above the ground at dusk, they're prepared, and everyone turns for home, fading through the grass before the predator has blinked the sleep out of its eyes.

fail_outcomes.text: The cats try to clean the opening to the sett free of tracks, but the ground is too damp and the dirt just ends up clumped oddly to their tails. Before they know it, they're tired, thirsty, and going home with nothing to show for it.

Well, the only way to know is to check! s_c scrambles into the den for a look, and it's only by the grace of StarClan that {PRONOUN/s_c/subject}{VERB/s_c/'re/'s} able to redirect that speed to twist around just as fast, furious fizzing following {PRONOUN/s_c/object} up the burrow tunnel, leaving behind clumps of {PRONOUN/s_c/poss} own fur.

intro_text: app1 runs along in the heat of the desert day, cajoling app2, who's really not keen on this sudden adventure during scorching-hot sunhigh.
decline_text: The apprentices are called back to camp to kitsit.

success_outcomes.text: Rounding a bend in the rocky path, app1 ducks under a thorn tree and through a gap between two rock pillars, and app2 emerges into the alcove beyond with a gasp. A little hidden pool lies perfectly still and quiet in the shade, and both apprentices leap into the water with exclamations of relief.

When app1 shows app2 the hidden pool {PRONOUN/app1/subject}{VERB/app1/'ve/'s} found, app2 can barely believe it! They spent the hot midday playing in the water, splashing, play-fighting, and having the time of their lives!

success_outcomes.text: Instead of working together, blood was spilled over every drop of water. Eventually, the medicine cats and mediators of the Clans were forced by Starclan to step in and end the carnage. But the damage was already done. c_n can learn from those mistakes - and how their ancestors had no choice but to live with them.

r_c has no time to be placated by stories. {PRONOUN/r_c/subject/CAP} {VERB/r_c/shove/shoves} to the front of the line, meeting p_l's gaze as {PRONOUN/r_c/subject} defiantly {VERB/r_c/drink/drinks} {PRONOUN/r_c/poss} fill.

intro_text: p_l notices app1 staring at a runnerbird thoughtfully, the tip of {PRONOUN/app1/poss} tail lashing. p_l ducks under the meager shade of a shrub to begin a story.
decline_text: app1 doesn't want a story, {PRONOUN/app1/subject} {VERB/app1/want/wants} a hunt.

success_outcomes.text: p_l weaves a tale of the runnerbird and the coyote, of hijinks and hazards, highlights and humour, {PRONOUN/p_l/poss} words making the apprentices first crouch in suspense then nearly fall over laughing, leaning on each other to stay upright. It's fun and games - but also a lesson in how hard runnerbirds are to catch.

fail_outcomes.text: app1 and app2 are off like a bolt before p_l can settle them, in fruitless pursuit of fast, alert, clever prey. p_l tries not to be smug when the apprentices slouch back, exhausted and prizeless, but it is a little funny.

The apprentices run off before p_l can start. Rolling {PRONOUN/p_l/poss} eyes, p_l settles down to wait. They return after a long time, tails dragging, panting and exhausted. Behind them, the runnerbird makes a disrespectful meep meep! call.

history_text.reg_death: m_c got dehydrated trying to outrun the thunderpath-runner bird.
history_text.lead_death: got dehydrated trying to outrun the thunderpath-runner bird

intro_text: The patrol stretches, fluffing out their pelts against the coming night as the stars begin to wake in the sky. p_l hums thoughtfully. There's an old tale of hairless monsters that nevertheless stalk the freezing darkness, unnatural reptiles that lack the sun-worship that defines their kind.
decline_text: A cold wind whistles through the rocks, uncomfortable and cutting, and p_l shakes {PRONOUN/p_l/poss} head. This is no time for storytelling; {PRONOUN/p_l/subject}'ll wait until everyone is tucked into a snug den instead.

success_outcomes.text: Once, long ago, a desert Clan refused to patrol their border, with no fear of their distant neighbours in a land too spacious for war. The chupacabra took advantage, sneaking through their lands undetected, sipping blood from cats at night. Even if c_n doesn't have enemy cats on their borders, that doesn't make the borderlands safe.

p_l starts telling the story of the deadly chupacabra - but s_c interrupts. {PRONOUN/s_c/subject/CAP} {VERB/s_c/think/thinks}, personally, that this particular tall tale is driven by a real concern. No, not a monster - mange, the hairloss that can leave an animal mindless with itch and reptilian in appearance. Worth thinking about.

fail_outcomes.text: p_l spins a chilling tale to the patrol - rumors of cats going missing in the frozen desert nights, or corpses found drained of blood, of a foul, reptilian horror... Too horrific, in fact. No one needed quite that much gory detail, thanks p_l.

intro_text: Today is a day for learning the best times to ambush lizards - early in the morning, while they're sitting on the basking rocks caught up in their daily ritual.
decline_text: app1 is also interested in this basking ritual, instead of in hunting lessons.

success_outcomes.text: As app1 stares at the lizards from afar, p_l tells the story of the dragons, who coveted fire and tried to eat the sun in their greed. The stars struck them down for their arrogance, stripping all their heat and flight, and now their long lost descendants come each morning to worship what they can never attain.

p_l makes sure app1 is focused. The ancestral cats who first discovered c_n's techniques found that by setting up ambushes in the rocks before dawn, the prey would come to them. This technique is why it's so important to understand which rocks the lizards flock to.

fail_outcomes.text: app1 is too impatient for {PRONOUN/app1/poss} lesson and runs off to try hunt. The rest of the patrol waits, mildly irritated, until they hear a yelp. app1 has gotten stuck upside down in a cervice a lizard escaped into, and lifting {PRONOUN/app1/object} out takes the rest of the morning.

intro_text: As the patrol pads forward in the dusty landscape, they spot a ball wobbling along, pushed by a gleaming scarab. A little Khepri!
decline_text: Weird, but not dangerous. The patrol moves on.

success_outcomes.text: It reminds s_c of an old tale. Khepri the sun beetle moves the sun across the sky, hiding it away at night in his burrow and awakening in the morning to push it along its tracks in the sky.
Scarabs bring luck, s_c says confidently. In times past, during period of great danger, desert cats would bring a scarab with them for luck, preferably a blue one.

fail_outcomes.text: app1 rolls {PRONOUN/app1/poss} eyes. A story about about dung beetles? Khepri is a dung bettle, s_c knows that, right? Please stop telling app1 about poop scarabs.

intro_text: p_l knows a really cool feature tucked into this canyon and flicks {PRONOUN/p_l/poss} tail to beckon the rest of the patrol. {PRONOUN/p_l/subject/CAP} {VERB/p_l/lead/leads} the patrol down, stopping in front of the lower half of a eroding rockface. Look - bones.
decline_text: Weird, but not dangerous. The patrol moves on.

success_outcomes.text: They're not bone-bone, p_l exlains, tracing a claw across the protruding skull. And they don't look like anything that currently walks the badlands. They're rock, but... bone shaped? p_l thinks these were a monster, one cursed by StarClan to be entombed by the rock until they became it.

Look at all the layers of rock above these, p_l whispers. How much time have these bones spent buried, only to be weathered out by water? What was this animal, nothing like a cat, what world did it live in, what wonders did it see? {PRONOUN/p_l/subject/CAP} {VERB/p_l/place/places} a paw on the skull's snout, staring into long-dead eyes.

fail_outcomes.text: No one else is interested in the strange rock-bones, and crestfallen, p_l tucks {PRONOUN/p_l/poss} tail as the patrol trudges out of the canyon.
